definition: Fu Shuo (c. 14th century BC), legendary sage and principal minister of Shang ruler Wu Ding
surname Fu
tutor
to persuade
to speak/to say/to explain/to scold/to tell off/a theory (typically the last character in a compound, as in 日心說|日心说 heliocentric theory)
variant of 說|说[shuo1]

sentences.english: King Wuding of the Shang Dynasty once lived here with his Prime Minister Fu Yue.
sentences.chinese: 这里啊曾经居住过商王武丁和他的宰相傅说。

sentences.english: King Wuding appreciated Fu's great talent and bold vision.
sentences.chinese: 武丁特别欣赏傅说的雄才大略。

definition: variant of 附會|附会[fu4 hui4]
to construct a rammed-earth wall
see Jiang Ziya 姜子牙[Jiang1 Zi3 ya2]

King Wen of Zhou state (c. 1152-1056 BC), reigned c. 1099-1056 BC as king of Zhou state, leading figure in building the subsequent Western Zhou dynasty, father of King Wu of Zhou 周武王[Zhou1 Wu3 wang2] the first Zhou dynasty king
Confucius (551-479 BC), Chinese thinker and social philosopher, also known as 孔夫子[Kong3 fu1 zi3]
see Jiang Ziya 姜子牙[Jiang1 Zi3 ya2]
Deng Xi (545-501 BC), Chinese philosopher and rhetorician, the first lawyer of ancient China
Guan Zhong (-645 BC), famous politician of Qi 齊國|齐国 of Spring and Autumn period/known as Guangzi 管子
a restricted view through a bamboo tube
King Wu of Zhou (-1043), personal name Ji Fa 姬發|姬发, reigned 1046-1043 BC as first king of Western Zhou dynasty 1046-1043 BC
Wu Ding (c. 14th century BC), legendary founder and wise ruler of Shang dynasty
Zi Gong or Duanmu Ci 端木賜|端木赐[Duan1 mu4 Ci4] (520 BC-), disciple of Confucius
Yu Shun, one of Five legendary Emperors 五帝[wu3 di4]
Huang Shigong, also known as Xia Huanggong 夏黃公|夏黄公[Xia4 Huang2 gong1] (dates of birth and death uncertain), Daoist hermit of the Qin Dynasty 秦代[Qin2 dai4] and purported author
Han Feizi, book of Legalist Philosophy authored by Han Fei 韓非|韩非[Han2 Fei1] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
another name for Laozi 老子[Lao3 zi3]
sagacious prime minister (in feudal China)
